hint: The upbeat is the last note in a bar, so in ${timeSignatures[timeSig][0]}/${timeSignatures[timeSig][1]}, it is the ${timeSignatures[timeSig][0]} beat.
Power-chords are made by only using the root and the fifth of a chord, which are the top two notes of a barre chord.

prompt: You can't play the low E string.
hint: The low E string is typically the string closest to your face that makes the lowest pitch.

prompt: Only play within the minor pentatonic.
hint: This is the minor pentatonic, it is shifted to be in the right keye-|O|-|-|O|B-|O|-|-|O|G-|O|-|O|-|D-|O|-|O|-|A-|O|-|O|-|E-|O|-|-|O|
For the key ${keys[key]}, the relative is ${keys[(Math.floor(key/2)*2)+1-(key%2)]}

prompt: Only play on every other bar.
hint: Each block on the chord chart is a bar, so alternate between playing on one and resting on the other.

prompt: Notes must start on the kick drum and end on the snare.
hint: Listen for your drummer and only start notes in the middle of their kick drum notes and start muting once they hit their snare.If you aren't familiar with what those sound like, ask your drummer!If you don't have a drummer, you lucked out! You get to play notes whenever you want!

prompt: You can't play the tonic of the chord.
hint: The tonic is the note a chord is named after. For example, if the chord is a C major, you can only play the E and G notes, and not the C.
Walking basslines go from one root note to the next chord's root note, usually not repeating any notes and only ascending or decenting in between.
Play twice as fast as you typically would.
You aren't allowed you use your kick drum or your snare. If another prompt requires that you do, try to do the next best thing, like stomping and clapping or even making noises with your mouth.
You aren't allowed to use any of your cymbals. Try to get creative with what you do still have!
If your keyboard has a sound library, load up an organ sound. If it doesn't, get as close as you can, either in tone or in technique.
If your keyboard has a sound library, load up the synthiest sound you have. If not, just try to match the vibe of 80s music in general.

prompt: Oops, you are a bass player now. Only play with your left hand.
hint: You might find yourself fighting with a bass player over those low notes. Fight to win!

prompt: Only sing on every other bar.
hint: Each block on the chord chart is a bar, so alternate between singing on one and resting on the other.
Turuya yabohuru wowesitu tubo sijiniba mejilawe wa sijimo!
If you don't know how to whistle, just 'ooh'.
If you have something soft to get on, try that, but if not you'll have to get on the ground!
I hope you vaccuum!

prompt: Plug your nose and read lyrics from a news article.
hint: A classic Bob Dylan impression. Pull out a boring article and just read the words in a nasally sing-songy voice!

prompt: Sing about the last meal you had.
hint: It can be about where you got it, who made it, what it was made with, who you were with, how it made you feel, etc! Just let the words and sounds flow!

prompt: Do an impression of a Beatle.
hint: It doesn't have to be good, just enough to move your voice to a place you don't explore that often.

prompt: Sing as softly as you can.
hint: Try to let others still hear you, but try to make it so that someone could fall asleep to your voice.
It doesn't have to be good, just enough to move your voice to a place you don't explore that often.If you have one already, do a Northern one, I guess!
It doesn't have to be good, just enough to move your voice to a place you don't explore that often.If you are already British, I'm so sorry.

prompt: You can't play the high E or B strings.
hint: These are the strings farthest from your head that make the highest pitched sounds.
Play mostly upstrokes and make a lot of space.
I'm not quite sure what this means either, but just imagine a stalk of wheat sticking out of your mouth and run with it!
Inversions are voicings where the root note, the note the chord is named after, is not the lowest note you play.

prompt: Play the relative major or minor on the tonic.
hint: Now, instead of playing the I, everyone plays the vi, or instead of the i, everyone plays the III! It is already changed in the chord chart.
Use short, quick notes, rather than long ones.
Use long, flowing notes, rather than short ones.

prompt: Sing with your throat as open as you can manage.
hint: It might sound funny, but it might sounds cool!

prompt: Strum each chord once at the start of the bar and let it ring out.
hint: Each block on the chord chart is a bar, so only play once when a new block lights up.
Use the palm of your picking hand to soften the sound and make it so that the strings don't ring out as long.

prompt: Throw in a few pinch harmonics.
hint: If you don't know how to do pinch harmonics, then congrats, you only have 1 prompt!

prompt: Try to play a lick others would recognize without them noticing.
hint: The lick can be from a famous song or meme, but try to sneak it in so others don't realize!

prompt: Throw in as many Nonharmonic tones as you can.
hint: These are notes that don't belong to the chord being played.

prompt: Do a mean impression of your favorite guitarist.
hint: If you love Jimmy Page, hit some bends a bit too far. If you love David Gilmour, only play a few notes. Get creative and get exaggeratory!

prompt: Play a guitar solo you know well that does NOT fit the chords or vibe.
hint: It doesn't matter what the song is, your hands want Hotel California!
It's ok to be a bit sharp.
If you don't have one, you can always use a cup, or even sometimes a tube of chapstick!
I hope you picking hand has some good calluses!
Get low and get riffy, and get rhythmic!

prompt: Play only two strings, where one is a drone note.
hint: Basically playing only on one string, but letting another string ring out with it.
You can't play on the downbeat, the 1.
It doesn't have to all be triplets, but build a feel around them and highlight them.

prompt: Build you bassline around eigth notes.
hint: It doesn't have to be all eigth notes, but use them generously and noticeably.
So when the band is playing the I, outline the Imaj7, or during the V outline the V7.
If you most often use your fingers, use a pick. If you most often use a pick, use your fingers. If split, use a coin.
Lightly rest your picking hand's palm over the strings so they never fully ring out.
Use a fuzz pedal. If you don't have one, try to crank your gain.

prompt: You can only use pedals and clap.
hint: You can still use your kick and hat, but your snare is all clapping now!
Like a disco song, play a slighly opened hi-hats on the 'and's.

prompt: Add an obnoxious amount of fills.
hint: The world is your drum solo, you are the star!

prompt: Be very sparce and create a lot of room.
hint: Like gentle parenting, you can encourage your band to go in the direction you want with more subtle direction.
Create some interesting rhythms with your snare, let it be the star of the show.
Don't just throw some triplets in, try to make your band mates start thinking in triplets, too.
At some point in the Jam, just put down your sticks and get up and leave for a little bit. Then come back and start drumming again without any comment.
If you need to look up some samba drum patterns, go for it. You can also just give a vaguely 'Spanish'-y vibe overall.

prompt: Only play chords on the beat before a chord change.
hint: Whether its on the upbeat or even the 'and' of it, the chords (not arpeggios or melodies) must be right before a chord change.
If your keyboard has a sound library, load up a harpsicord sound. If it doesn't, get as close as you can, either in tone or in baroque-ish technique.
Every note you play must be higher than the note that came before it, resetting on each chord change.

prompt: Use the silliest sounds your keyboard can make.
hint: Whether it is sound effects or harsh noise or a sample that doesn't make much sense, try to bring in some chaos to the Jam and make it work!
Whether its on the upbeat or even the 'and' of it, play the upcoming tonic (root note) right before a chord change.
Whether its on the upbeat or even the 'and' of it, play the chord right before a chord change.
